definitions.definition: belonging to somebody; relating to somebody

examples.text: the love of a mother for her child
Can't you throw out that old bike of Tommy's?

definitions.definition: belonging to something; being part of something; relating to something
coming from a particular background or living in a place
used to say what somebody/something is, consists of or contains
used with measurements and expressions of time, age, etc.

examples.text: We would often have a walk of an evening.

definitions.definition: used to show somebody/something belongs to a group, often after some, a few, etc.

examples.text: the most famous of all the stars

definitions.definition: used to show the position of something/somebody in space or time

examples.text: at the time of the revolution
at a quarter of eleven tonight *(= 10.45 p.m.)*

definitions.definition: used after nouns formed from verbs. The noun after ‘of’ can be either the object or the subject of the action.

examples.text: the arrival of the police *(= they arrive)*
criticism of the police *(= they are criticized)*

definitions.definition: used after some verbs before mentioning somebody/something involved in the action

examples.text: He was cleared of all blame.
Think of a number, any number.

definitions.definition: used after some adjectives before mentioning somebody/something that a feeling relates to
used to give your opinion of somebody’s behaviour

examples.text: It was kind of you to offer.

definitions.definition: used when one noun describes a second one

examples.text: Where's that idiot of a boy *(= the boy that you think is stupid)*?

definitions.definition: used before a noun to say that something is very surprising

examples.text: I'm surprised that you of all people should say that.

wordOrigin: Old English, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch af and German ab, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin ab and Greek apo.
